title: Thug bludgeoned Good Samaritan with claw hammer days after she took him in
text:
Gareth Nott battered his host with a claw hammer before throttling her (Picture: Cleveland Police)

A thug who bludgeoned a Good Samaritan with a claw hammer and left her with ‘truly awful injuries’ just days after she took him in was jailed for more than 10 years.

The woman lent money to her friend Gareth Nott and let him stay at her home on Boxing Day last year after finding out he had no funds of his own and no gas.

He repaid the act of kindness by subjecting her to a ‘disturbingly’ vicious attack while she slept on the couch four days later on December 30.

She woke to find Nott, 33, sitting astride her on the floor raining down a barrage of punches.

After delivering ‘too many blows to count’ as well as two headbutts Nott donned a pair of oven gloves, picked up a claw hammer and begun battering her to the head, face, chest, neck and arms.

When she ‘decided to play dead’ in a desperate attempt to halt the onslaught, Nott started beating her again after hearing her breathing, prosecutor Harry Hadfield said.

Nott was jailed for 10-and-a-half years for the ‘ferocious attack’ (Picture: Cleveland Police)

Nott, from Hartlepool, was arrested the following day, New Year’s Eve, stepping off a train in Lincoln wearing the same bloodied clothes.

He admitted grievous bodily harm with intent at Teesside Crown Court and was jailed for 10-and-a-half years with an extended licence period of four years.

The court heard the woman’s ordeal lasted more than two-and-a-half hours.

She was left with two swollen black eyes, a broken nose, more than a dozen cuts, numerous bruises and wounds which caused permanent scarring to her head and face.

In a victim impact statement read to the court she said she has to wear a wig because of her injuries and suffers daily panic attacks and flashbacks.

Jailing him, Judge Howard Crowson told Nott: ‘She was your host and you were her guest. She was entitled to feel safe.

‘It was clearly a wholly motiveless attack. It was a ferocious attack. She thought she would die. That’s hardly surprising.

‘It was an attack on a very vulnerable woman asleep in her own home. The injuries are truly awful.’

Detective Sergeant Mark Hanson from Hartlepool CID added: ‘This sentence reflects the fact that the victim was subject to a sustained and violent attack, disturbingly begun when she was sleeping.

‘Clearly this will have a lasting impact on her life. We welcome today’s sentence which will mean a dangerous offender will serve a lengthy jail term.’
